questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was referred by a dentist after she was found to have loss of lamina dura in the tooth. Her radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of the skull shows multiple radiolucent lytic lesions with a salt and pepper appearance/pepperpot appearance. The clinical scenario and X-ray features are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism.

Radiological features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges
    • Pathognomonic feature 
    • Seen especially in the second and third fingers
    • Also visualized in the lateral end of the clavicle and symphysis pubis
  • Loss of lamina dura 
    • Thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth
    • Seen as a thin white line
  • Brown’s tumor
    • Expansile lytic lesion generally affecting maxilla/mandible
  • Salt and pepper appearance of the skull
  • Generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae

A radiograph showing subperiosteal cortical resorption is given below.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented to the outpatient department with dysphagia. Barium swallow was done and it showed the following finding in the lower end of the esophagus. The most probable cause is
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, is Schatzki’s ring.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction. It is often associated with hiatal hernia. The patient experiences brief episodes of dysphagia during hurried ingestion of solid foods.

The presence of a ring in the esophagus, with or without hiatal hernia, can be visualized on barium swallow.

Treatment:

For symptomatic patients who do not have reflux, the best form of treatment consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is done to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of repeated chest infections with the presence of large amounts of sputum in a non-smoker point to the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. The CT scan showing the signet ring sign is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheeze, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis along with low-grade fever, and weight loss. On CT, Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy can be seen.

The image given below shows cavities in pulmonary tuberculosis:

 

Option C: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease on imaging. 

Option D: Patients with bronchial asthma present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. On CT, bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping is seen.

  • Mildest form of bronchiectasis
  • Loss of normal airway tapering
  • Bronchi have a uniform calibre, have parallel walls tram track sign and signet ring sign
  • Further distortion of the airway wall along with more mucous and sputum production
  • Beaded bronchi with interspersed sites of relative narrowing
  • Most severe form of bronchiectasis and least common
  • This form has large air spaces and a honeycombed appearance
  • Air fluid levels present

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the classic CT appearance seen in patients with acute subdural hematoma?
questions.solution:
A crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines on axial CT is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. 

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhage are:

  • Typically unilateral
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain
  • Not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections
  • Chronic subdural hemorrhage: Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT
  • Acute subdural hemorrhage: Hyperdense collections on CT

A lentiform (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion that does not cross suture lines on axial CT is suggestive of an epidural hemorrhage.

The image given below shows a subdural hematoma with a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion on CT:

 

The image given below is that of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage seen on CT:

 

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of cough and fever. Chest X-ray shows obliteration of the right cardiac border. Which anatomical site is likely involved in the pathology?
questions.solution:
Obliteration of the right cardiac border on chest X-ray indicates pathology in the right middle lobe.

This loss of clear demarcation between the normal lung and its surrounding soft structures (heart, diaphragm) is called the silhouette sign. It occurs due to loss of contrast between lungs and soft tissue when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air. This sign may be seen in consolidation, atelectasis, or mass lesions.

In the following images:

  • Left image - red line indicates the normal demarcation between the right heart border and middle lobe of the right lung
  • Right image - loss of demarcation (positive silhouette sign) due to right middle lobe consolidation

Positive silhouette sign and corresponding anatomical site of pathology:

  • Right heart border - right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe
  • Left heart border - lingula segments of the left upper lobe
  • Left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta - left lower lobe
  • Aortic knuckle - left upper lobe (posterior segment)
  • Right hemidiaphragm - right lower lobe
  • Right paratracheal stripe - right upper lobe

questions.text: On a CT scan, intracranial calcifications seen in all of the following structures are considered normal in the elderly population, except ___________.
questions.solution:
The red nucleus is not a usual site of normal intracranial calcification.

Sites of normal intracranial calcification, visible on CT scan are:

  • Pineal
  • Habenula
  • Choroid plexuses
  • Dura (falx; tentorium; over vault)
  • Ligaments (petroclinoid and interclinoid)
  • Pacchionian bodies
  • Basal ganglia and dentate nuclei
  • Pituitary gland

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of hypertension, presented with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed an aortic dissection involving only the descending thoracic aorta, not extending into the abdominal aorta. According to DeBakey's classification, the aortic dissection is classified as ______.
questions.solution:
According to DeBakey's classification, the aortic dissection limited to the descending thoracic aorta is classified as DeBakey type IIIa.

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear, which allows blood to penetrate into the medial layer, producing a cleavage plane (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimo-medial flap. It most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing chest/back pain. It is associated with diaphoresis. Other symptoms are syncope, weakness, and dyspnea.

On examination, there can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological manifestations. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double-lumen aorta.

A young female patient with a history of renal calculi presents with bone pain and abdominal cramps. On investigation, multiple fractures and raised levels of serum calcium and PTH are noted. Which of the following will be the best investigation to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?

PTH- Parathormone
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. Sestamibi scan is the best investigation for parathyroid abnormalities. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma.

Sestamibi is a monovalent, lipophilic cation that passively diffuses across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria.

There are mainly two techniques used to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue:

  • Subtraction imaging - This method uses a dual radionu­clide approach with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or either 99mTc pertechnetate.
  • Dual-phase imaging - This method uses sesta­mibi alone with early and delayed imaging.

Sestamibi single-photon emission CT has become the most commonly used preoperative imaging study in parathyroid disease because of its improved spatial resolution.

Sestamibi combined with computed tomography (CT) offers the advantage of detecting smaller parathyroid lesions that would otherwise be undetectable with sestamibi alone.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows air bronchogram sign in a lung with consolidation, seen in pneumonia, which is supported by the clinical history of this patient.

An air bronchogram is a tubular outline of an airway made visible when there is filling of the surrounding alveoli by fluid or inflammatory exudates.

The causes of air bronchogram are as follows:

  • Lung consolidation
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Nonobstructive pulmonary atelectasis
  • Severe interstitial disease
  • Neoplasm
  • Normal expiration

Pleural effusion is seen as a homogenous opacity on chest radiograph.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with history of squamous cell carcinoma lung presents with shortness of breath. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the golden S sign which is seen in the right upper lobe collapse.

Golden S-sign is seen on both PA chest radiographs and on CT scans in the right upper lobe collapse. It is named because this sign resembles a reverse S shape, and is therefore sometimes referred to as the reverse S-sign of Golden. 

Although typically seen with the right upper lobe collapse, the S-sign can also be seen with the collapse of other lobes. It is created by a central mass obstructing the upper lobe bronchus. It should raise suspicion of a primary bronchogenic carcinoma. It can also be caused by other central masses, such as metastasis, primary mediastinal tumor, or enlarged lymph nodes.

The additional finding in this X-ray is the presence of calcified breast implants.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident and eFAST was performed on him. Which among the following statements is true regarding eFAST?

choices.text: It detects free fluid in the abdomen or pericardium
It helps in assessment of retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
eFAST/extended FAST helps in detecting free fluid in the abdomen and pericardium. 

Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) aims to identify intra-abdominal free fluid (assumed to be hemoperitoneum in the context of trauma) allowing for an immediate transfer for surgery or for CT imaging and further workup.

The standard order of evaluation is:

  • Pericardial (subxiphoid)
  • Right flank (perihepatic view or Morison's pouch)
  • Left flank (perisplenic view)
  • Pelvic (retrovesical views)

eFAST (Extended FAST) is used to assess pleural (pneumothorax and hemothorax evaluation), pericardial region, right flank, left flank, and pelvic region. It is accurate in detecting >100 ml of free blood. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose. It is also unreliable in excluding injury in penetrating trauma. It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

questions.text: A high-resolution CT image of the chest is shown below. Which of the following conditions is it most likely suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The HRCT image shows sandstorm appearance and black pleura sign characteristic of pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis.

Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis occurs due to the deposition of small calcium and phosphate stones (<3mm) within the alveoli. The stones are of unknown origin.

Radiological features:

  • CXR/CT shows widespread, discrete, high-density opacities, resembling the grains of sand in both the lungs. The appearance is commonly described as sand-storm appearance.
  • Profuse infiltration may appear as white-out, with obscuration of the heart borders and diaphragm.
  • The presence of small cysts (5-10 mm) or paraseptal emphysema, may cause the pleura to appear a black, lucent line lying between the pulmonary infiltrate and the adjacent ribs, referred to as ‘black-pleura sign’.
  • Bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities with nodular thickening along the fissures and interlobar septa produce a crazy-paving pattern.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with seizures and her radiological image is as given below. Knowing that the MR spectroscopy of the lesion showed elevated choline, alanine, and lactate, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiological image and history of seizures suggests a diagnosis of neurocysticercosis. 

Neurocysticercosis presents with seizures, hydrocephalus, raised ICP, and may even cause signs of chronic meningitis. The given image shows multilobulated cystic lesions (with scolex) in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulose). 

  • Cyst with a dot sign: seen in both MRI and CT and the dot represents the eccentrically placed scolex of the parasite.

MR Spectroscopy features of neurocysticercosis include elevated lactate, alanine, succinate, and choline levels and reduced levels of N -acetyl aspartate and creatine. Escobar's pathological stages describe 4 stages - vesicular, colloidal vesicular, granular nodular, and nodular calcified. 

Other options

  • Solid or ring enhancement is typical in the post-contrast images of tuberculoma. A central focus of calcification with a ring of peripheral enhancement (the "target sign") is also described in tuberculosis but is not specific to it.
  • Cerebral toxoplasmosis appears as multiple hypodense regions predominantly in the basal ganglia and at the corticomedullary junction. It can be associated with ring enhancing lesions as well.
  • Cryptococcosis is usually associated with normal scans but may show cerebral atrophy, hydrocephalus or mass lesions as well.

questions.text:
Match the following Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) findings and the conditions associated with them.
1) Cobra neck appearance a) Retroperitoneal fibrosis
2) Maiden waist sign b) Retrocaval ureter
3) Paintbrush appearance c) Ureterocele
4) Fishhook ureters d) Medullary sponge kidney
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b (option B).

IVP sign Condition
1. Cobra neck appearance c. Ureterocele
2. Maiden waist sign a. Retroperitoneal fibrosis
3. Paintbrush appearance d. Medullary sponge kidney
4. Fishhook ureters b. Retrocaval ureter 

 

Cobra neck appearance - It is also called the cobra head sign or the spring onion sign and is seen in the ureterocele. It refers to dilatation of the distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim to the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. It is seen in patients with an adult-type ureterocele. The cobra head appearance indicates an uncomplicated ureterocele.

 

Maiden waist deformity: It refers to the appearance of the medial deviation of bilateral ureters. This is typically seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis. In this condition, there is a medial drawing of the ureter due to the deposition of fibrous tissue in the lumbosacral junction. Due to the involvement of both ureters, the course of the medially-drawn ureters has an appearance of a narrow maiden waist, thus giving the name.

 

Paintbrush appearance - It refers to the appearance of dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla and is seen in the medullary sponge kidney. Another typical finding in medullary sponge kidney is the bouquet of flower appearance. 

Image of medullary sponge kidney showing paintbrush and bouquet of flower appearance:

 

Fish hook ureter: 

  • Right-sided fish hook ureter describes the appearance of the retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.
  • Bilateral Fishhook ureters (J-shaped ureters or hockey stick ureters) describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient approached a radiologist for a screening breast examination during breast cancer awareness month. Which of the following best represents the difference in the  X-ray tube used in this procedure from that of a conventional X-ray machine?

choices.text: Beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter
Glass exit window and aluminium filter
Beryllium exit window and aluminium filter
Glass exit window and molybdenum filter

questions.solution:
The screening procedure for breast cancer is mammography. The x-ray tube used in mammography differs from that of a conventional x-ray machine in that it has a beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter.

Differences between mammography and conventional radiography:

  • Mammography involves the use of low-energy and high-amperage waves.
  • The target anode is made of a tungsten disc in conventional x-ray tubes and molybdenum in mammography x-ray tubes.
  • Most mammography tubes use beryllium exit windows between the evacuated tube and the atmosphere.
  • The conventional X-ray tube has an aluminum filter, but in mammography, a molybdenum filter is used.

Some indications for mammography:

  • Evaluation of breast signs and symptoms like masses, skin changes, deformities, nipple retraction, discharge, and eczema
  • Breast cancer screening
  • Follow-up for patients treated for breast cancer
  • Localization of lesions not visible on ultrasound

The two standard mammographic projections are the mediolateral oblique view and the craniocaudal view.

Note: Breast cancer awareness month is an annual international health campaign organized by major breast cancer charities every year in the month of October.

questions.text: A patient's gall bladder has the following appearance on MRI. What is the most likely interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given appearance of the gallbladder is known as a Phrygian cap, which is a normal anatomical variant.

Phrygian cap refers to an anatomical variant of the gallbladder, where the gallbladder's fundus folds on itself or is separated from the body by a partial or complete septum. A true septum is uncommon and is usually an apparent septum due to the gallbladder wall folding. It is an incidental finding that may be seen on CT, MRI, or ultrasound. It causes no symptoms.

The Phrygian cap is named so, due to the resemblance of the ultrasonographic appearance to a hat or cap that is worn by the inhabitants of ancient Phrygia circa 1200 BC.

The image below shows a Phrygian cap:

 

Other options:

Option a: Cholangiocarcinoma is an adenocarcinoma originating from the bile duct. It is diagnosed based on a CT/MRI. Depending on the type of tumor, the findings may include capsular retraction, biliary dilatation, or wall thickening.

Option b: Choledochal cyst or biliary cystic disease commonly presents in childhood with pain, jaundice, and a right upper quadrant mass. MRCP is the preferred investigation.

Option c: Caroli's disease refers to a sporadic condition characterized by the formation of intrahepatic biliary cysts. USG /CT reveals the beaded appearance of the intrahepatic bile ducts with multiple cystic structures. It is characteristically associated with the central dot sign.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows splenic laceration. 

Splenic lacerations are linear low attenuation parenchymal defects and are almost always associated with haemoperitoneum.

The spleen is the visceral organ most commonly injured in blunt trauma abdomen. Severely ill patients may present with hypovolemic shock manifesting as tachycardia, hypotension, and pallor. A splenic rupture may not always be clinically apparent and spontaneous splenic rupture or pathological rupture can occur after minor trauma or insignificant events.

Investigation of choice in blunt trauma abdomen is CECT.

Splenic injury are currently classified into five grades based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) splenic injury scale (revised in 2018).

Management of splenic trauma:

  • Nonoperative management is preferred for stable grade I, II, or III splenic injuries.
  • Splenectomy is done for grade IV and V injuries.

questions.text:
Which of the following MRI imaging techniques produce a bright cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) appearance?
  1. T1 weighted image
  2. T2 weighted image
  3. STIR
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
A bright CSF appearance is seen in T2 weighted images and STIR (Short tau inversion recovery).

T1 weighted images:

  • It is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences.
  • The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times.
  • CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark.

T2 weighted images:

  • It is also a basic MRI pulse sequence.
  • It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues.
  • CSF appears bright in these images.

 

Short tau inversion recovery(STIR):

  • It is a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fat.
  • The imaging sequence is identified by observing the fat tissues and fluid-filled spaces.
  • Fluids like CSF appear bright and fat appears dark.

 

Fluid attenuated inversion recovery(FLAIR):

  • It is also a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fluids.
  • Fluids like CSF appear dark and pathological processes appear bright.
  • It would appear as a fluid suppressed T2 image.

questions.text: A neonate who was apparently normal at birth is brought to the emergency department with complaints of bilious vomiting. An upper gastrointestinal barium study was done and the image is given below. Identify the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows the corkscrew sign which is a characteristic radiographic finding in midgut volvulus.

Midgut volvulus is a complication of malrotation of the bowel and may result in proximal bowel obstruction. It can occur at any age but it is commonly seen in the first few months of life. The baby presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal pain, and failure to thrive.

Characteristic radiographic signs include:

  • Corkscrew sign - It is a barium meal study finding seen in midgut volvulus. It describes the spiraling of the duodenum and jejunum around the mesenteric vessels. 
    It has been identified as a diagnostic indicator of midgut volvulus.
  • Whirlpool sign - It is also known as the whirl sign. It is seen due to the rotation of the bowel around the mesentery leading to whorls of mesenteric vessels. It can be seen in ultrasound and CT scans.

The whirlpool sign on a CT is shown below:

Rigler's sign - It is also known as the double wall sign and it is an abdominal radiograph finding in pneumoperitoneum. Here, both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible. 

Coffee bean sign - It is also known as the kidney bean sign or the bent inner-tube sign. It is a plain abdominal radiograph finding in the sigmoid volvulus, shown below.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text:
Which of the following tumors are wrongly matched with their response to radiotherapy?

RCC-Renal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Dysgerminoma is highly radiosensitive. All other options are correctly matched.

Dysgerminoma is the counterpart of testicular seminoma. It may occur in childhood, but 75% occur in the second and third decades. 80 to 90% of tumors are unilateral. Some appear in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. 

Mostly dysgerminomas are malignant with variable degrees of histologic atypia and one-third of lesions are aggressive. 

Radiotherapy is not preferred despite the fact that they are radiosensitive due to the risk of radiation injury to the bowel. These neoplasms are responsive to chemotherapy, which is preferred over radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors and adjuvant radiotherapy was the mainstay of treatment in Stage 1 tumors previously.

Option C: Spinal metastasis from renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is radioresistant. Spinal metastasis from gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma, metastatic melanoma, and thyroid are also radioresistant. Lymphoma, lung, breast, and prostate metastasis are radiosensitive.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is a radiosensitive tumor.

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient who is admitted to the intensive care unit for pneumonia suddenly develops breathing difficulty and tachycardia. On auscultation, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side. A portable chest X-ray was taken in the supine position, and it showed the deep sulcus sign.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, sudden deterioration in pre-existing pneumonia with reduced breath sounds suggests secondary spontaneous pneumothorax and the presence of the deep sulcus sign on the chest X-ray confirms the diagnosis. 

A deep sulcus sign is a supine radiograph finding indicative of pneumothorax. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally within the nondependent portions of the pleural space.

In chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients there may be the presence of deepened costophrenic angles due to hyperinflation of the lungs which can cause a false deep sulcus sign.

The image below shows the deep sulcus sign seen on a chest radiograph:

Pneumothorax is the accumulation of air within the pleural space. It may occur as a result of trauma, surgery, needle aspiration, central line insertion, increased pressure from mechanical ventilation, lung diseases or other conditions.

Other chest radiograph findings in pneumothorax:  

  • Visceral pleural edge appears as a very thin, sharp white line and no lung markings are seen peripheral to this line.
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent when compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless there is the presence of a tension pneumothorax.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with opacification of the hemithorax on chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Opacification of the hemithorax on chest X-ray is not seen in Macleod syndrome; it causes hyper translucent hemithorax. All the other conditions mentioned produce an opacification of the hemithorax or white-out hemithorax.

Causes of opacification of a hemithorax:

  • Pleural effusion
  • Consolidation
  • Collapse
  • Massive tumor
  • Fibrothorax
  • Combination of the above lesions
  • Pneumonectomy
  • Lung agenesis

Macleod syndrome or Swyer-James syndrome: It results from an insult to the lower respiratory following adenovirus (most commonly) or respiratory syncytial virus, measles, or mycoplasma pneumonia. It refers to the inability of the lungs to grow after severe obstructive bronchiolitis.

Causes for unilateral hyper translucent hemithorax:

  • Rotation due to poor patient positioning– most common
  • Scoliosis
  • Mastectomy
  • Pneumothorax
  • Emphysema
  • Macleod syndrome
  • Poland syndrome
  • Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 44-year-old man who works as an operator in the CT room is being evaluated for radiation exposure using the equipment shown below. Which of the following is not a constituent of this badge?
questions.solution:
The given shows a TLD badge (thermoluminescent dosimeter) which is used for personal radiation dose monitoring. Lead is not a constituent of this badge.

Lead is not a component of the TLD badge but lead is used to offer radiation shielding. Lead aprons are commonly used to safeguard from scattered radiation.

The thermoluminescent material used in them is calcium sulfate doped with dysprosium or lithium fluoride. The radiation exposure is monitored every 3 months. The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices.

In India, the TLD badge is worn inside the lead apron at the chest level. The maximum dose limit for occupational radiation workers is 30 mSv in a year provided the cumulative dose in a block of 5 years does not exceed 100 mSv. 

Acute Radiation Syndromes (ARS) is an acute illness that is caused by exposure of the entire body to a high dose of penetrating radiation in a very short period of time. It is also known as radiation toxicity or radiation sickness. It consists of three syndromes:

Syndrome   Radiation dose
Hematopoietic
(Bone marrow)		  >0.7 Gy  
Gastrointestinal   >10 Gy  
Cardiovascular/ Central nervous system   >50 Gy  

Stages of ARS include: 

  • Prodromal phase - manifests with non-specific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Early and persistent symptoms predict severity.
  • Latent phase - the patient looks and feels generally healthy for a few hours or even up to a few weeks. In severe cases, this phase may be absent.
  • Manifest illness phase - symptoms are seen as per the radiation dose. Tissues with greater rates of cellular division are most radiosensitive, and hence the hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems are the most affected.
  • Recovery phase or Death - this begins when the patient recovers from the acute exposure.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with complaints of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. She was hospitalized for pneumonia and was on antibiotic therapy with clindamycin. Sigmoidoscopy revealed multiple yellowish plaques from the rectum to the sigmoid colon; her CECT image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the CT image showing the accordion sign, is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis.

The accordion sign or concertina sign is seen in the CT abdomen of patients with pseudomembranous colitis. It refers to the thickened edematous bowel appearing similar to the folds of an accordion. This appearance is caused by the stretching of the hyperemic, enhancing mucosa over the thickened submucosal folds. This is also seen when the contrast agent is trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes of the colon.

The accordion sign is typical for pseudomembranous colitis but can be also seen in the following conditions:

  • Ischemic colitis
  • AIDS-related colitis
  • Severe edema from cirrhosis

Pseudomembranous colitis: It is usually caused by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile. It is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes C. difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of this condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). 

PMC is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers. can persist on surfaces for months. Risk factors include poor hand hygiene, old age, and gastrointestinal surgery.

The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially, which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and the detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 

Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

Other options:

Option B: In Ogilvie syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction, a massively dilated colon without any mechanical obstruction is seen. It is a functional disorder, usually associated with narcotics, bed rest, and comorbidities.

Option C: Toxic megacolon appears as a massively dilated colon with additional loss of haustral markings with pseudopolyps on CT.

Option D: Sigmoid volvulus appears as a coffee-bean or bent inner tube sign on plain x-ray and shows the pathognomonic bird's beak sign on gastrografin enema.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A  54-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of chest pain and breathing difficulty. On examination, there is tachypnea and tachycardia. Chest x-ray shows Westermark's sign and Hampton's hump. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the presence of Westermark's sign and Hampton's hump on radiography are suggestive of pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism is an embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. X-ray is neither sensitive nor specific for pulmonary embolism diagnosis. It is used to exclude differential diagnostic possibilities such as pneumonia and pneumothorax rather than directly diagnosing a pulmonary embolism. CT pulmonary angiography is the investigation of choice in pulmonary embolism.

Described chest radiographic signs include:

  • Fleishner's sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.
  • Westermark's sign is a chest x-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyperlucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.

Chest x-ray demonstrating Westermark sign:

 

  • Hampton's hump refers to the pleural-based, peripheral wedge-shaped opacity with its apex pointing towards the occluding vessel. It implies lung infarction and is usually not seen in the first 24 hours of pulmonary embolism.

 

  • ‘Knuckle’ or ‘sausage’ sign - It refers to dilatation of a central pulmonary artery due to occlusion by the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.
  • Palla’s sign - dilated right descending pulmonary artery

The image below shows Palla's sign:

 

  • Other secondary radiographic findings include elevated hemidiaphragm, pleural effusion, and plate-like atelectasis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is being evaluated for epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few weeks. He also gives a history of occasional black discoloration of the stools. A barium study was done for the patient. Which of the following findings on barium study would indicate that the ulcer is benign?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gastric ulcers and the presence of Hampton's lines on barium study would indicate that the gastric ulcer is benign.

Hampton's line is a thin radiolucent line seen at the base of a gastric ulcer in barium studies. It represents the preserved gastric mucosa with undermining of the more vulnerable submucosa. It indicates the benign nature of the gastric ulcer.

Other features of a benign ulcer include:

  • The smooth rim of lucency at the base of the ulcer.
  • Converging folds
  • Round, linear, or oval-shaped ulcer
  • Symmetrical, gently sloping ulcer mass.

Difference between benign and malignant gastric ulcer:

Extends beyond the gastric wall Yes No
Folds Smooth, even Irregular, nodular, may fuse

Carman meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers. It refers to the lenticular shape of barium in the shallow/flat malignant ulcer, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen. Other features of malignant ulcers include irregular ulcer, nodular mound, and thickened, irregular interrupted, and fused folds around the ulcer, loss of mucosal pattern, and incomplete healing.

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby is being evaluated for recurrent seizure episodes. On examination, a port-wine stain is seen on the face of the child. A CT was done and the image is given below. Which of the following is the typical radiological finding in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows tram track calcification seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. The clinical features of facial port-wine stain and seizures also favor the diagnosis.

The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex, seen in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine stain along the course of the trigeminal nerve
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities

Other options:

Option B: Dawson's fingers: They are periventricular demyelinating plaques perpendicular to the body of lateral ventricles seen in multiple sclerosis. The image below shows Dawson's fingers.

 

Option C: Hot cross bun sign: It is due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy. It is shown in the image below:

 

Option D: Molar tooth sign: It refers to the abnormal anteroposterior orientation of the cerebellar peduncles resembling the roots of a molar tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome (cerebellar vermian dysgenesis). It is shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient complained of pain after an injury to his left knee while playing football. MRI showed a bucket-handle tear of the medial meniscus. The anterior cruciate ligament was intact. Which of the following radiographic findings best describes this condition?

(PCL- posterior cruciate ligament)
questions.solution:
The double PCL sign is the radiographic finding seen on a sagittal MRI image in a bucket-handle medial meniscal tear with an intact anterior cruciate ligament.

Double PCL sign: Here, the bucket handle fragment of the torn meniscus is seen as a low-signal structure lying parallel to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), mimicking a second smaller PCL.

A bucket-handle tear occurs when there is a vertical split in the meniscus, and the separated fragment of the meniscus remains attached in the front and back. The medial meniscus is involved in 80% of the cases. 

An intact anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is required to appreciate the double PCL sign in medial meniscal tears as it prevents the flipped meniscal fragment from further lateral movement.

In very few cases, the double PCL sign is seen with bucket-handle tears involving the lateral meniscus.

Meniscal tears can be horizontal and vertical.

Horizontal tears are frequently degenerative in nature and asymptomatic. Joint fluid may escape through this tear and form a parameniscal cyst.

Vertical tears can be of two types: longitudinal and radial.

Longitudinal tears:

  • They lie within the substance of the menisci and track circumferentially.
  • It usually involves the periphery of the meniscus, where the blood supply is better, and may heal spontaneously.

Radial tears:

  • It extends radially from the free edges into the meniscus, and it can be of several forms.
  • Parrot -beak tear: Small oblique slit-like radial tear
  • Ghost meniscus sign: It refers to the MRI appearance of a complete radial tear, usually involving the posterior root of the meniscus. It is so called because the meniscus disappears and then reappears like a "ghost" on consecutive sagittal sequences. 

Note: The double Oreo cookie sign is seen in injuries to the glenoid labrum. (option D)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with 6 months history of postprandial fullness, bloating, abdominal pain, and recurrent episodes of non-bloody diarrhea. The given clinical features are of Crohn's disease and the barium study image shows the string sign of Kantor. It refers to a narrowed length of the terminal ileum.

  • Cobblestone appearance: It is due to the combination of longitudinal and transverse ulcerations separating intact portions of the mucosa. 
  • Kantor string sign: It refers to the long lengths of narrowed terminal ileum seen in long-standing disease.
  • Creeping fat sign: It refers to the widely separated bowel loops due to fibrofatty proliferation.

Findings on CT or MR enterography include:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of new-onset left-sided chest pain. He had a recent history of a viral infection. ECG showed diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and echocardiography detected a pericardial effusion. What is the finding that can be seen on the chest radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of pericardial effusion as a result of acute pericarditis. The chest radiograph may show a water-bottle configuration due to enlargement of the cardiac silhouette because of the pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion is usually associated with chest pain and/or the ECG changes of pericarditis (widespread ST elevation, often with upward concavity). If the effusion is large, the ECG may show electrical alternans. Heart sounds may be faint, friction rub, and the apical impulse may not be audible.

Echocardiography is a widely used imaging technique that allows localization and estimation of the quantity of pericardial fluid.

The chest X-ray shows an enlargement of the cardiac silhouette- water-bottle configuration. It may be normal in small effusions. The lateral radiograph may show the oreo cookie sign. It is a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line (paracardial fat) directly behind the sternum anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical line (epicardial fat) posteriorly. 

CT and MRI are indicated when echocardiography is inconclusive, when the effusion is loculated or hemorrhagic or if there is pericardial thickening.

Other options:

Option B: A boot-shaped heart is seen in patients with Tetrology of Fallot. It refers to the appearance of an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy. 

Option C: Batwing appearance is seen in pulmonary edema. It refers to the appearance of perihilar consolidation.

Option D: The figure 3 sign is seen in the aortic coarctation. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and indentation of the left subclavian artery at the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be classified as ionizing radiation?
  1. Alpha rays
  2. Beta rays
  3. Gamma rays
  4. X-rays
  5. MRI
questions.solution:
Among the given options, alpha rays, beta rays, gamma rays, and x-rays are ionizing radiations. MRI is an example of non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. 

Ionizing radiation is a type of radiation with enough energy to remove tightly bound electrons from the orbit of an atom, causing the atom to be charged or ionized. They can be either directly ionizing or indirectly ionizing. Alpha rays and beta rays are directly ionizing radiation because they carry a charge and can directly interact with atomic electrons. Alpha and beta rays are also particulate radiation (composed of particles). 

Gamma rays and x-rays are electromagnetic rays. They are indirectly ionizing radiation as they are electrically neutral and do not interact directly with electrons. 

MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves. It uses non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. MRI is based on the ability of nuclei of certain atoms to absorb and emit radio wave energy when the body is placed within a strong magnetic field.

questions.text: You are being asked to describe a normal chest X-ray in your final year practical examination. Which of the following statement is false regarding a normal chest radiograph?

choices.text: Lower lobe veins contribute significantly to the hilar shadow
Poor inspiratory effort produces prominent pulmonary vessels
Medial borders of the clavicles should be equidistant from the spinous process
Left dome of diaphragm is lower than right

questions.solution:
The blood vessels that contribute significantly to the hilar shadow in a normal chest X-ray are the upper lobe veins, not the lower lobe veins.

Features of a normal chest radiograph

  • An ideal chest radiograph should not be rotated. No rotation implies that the distance between the medial end of the clavicle and the spinous process should be equidistant on both sides.
  • A good inspiratory effort is also important in an ideal radiograph.
  • With poor inspiratory effort, pulmonary vessels become more prominent and a false diagnosis of cardiac failure will be made.
  • In a normal chest X-ray, the left dome of the diaphragm is lower than the right because the heart pushes the left dome down.
  • In 97% of the cases, the left hilum is higher than the right hilum and in 3% both are at the same level.
  • The pulmonary arteries and the upper lobar veins contribute significantly to the hilar shadow on a plain radiograph.

The most commonly used and preferred view is the PA view (posteroanterior view).

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from a poor family is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of purpuric rash and pain in the limbs. Examination revealed bleeding from swollen gums and petechiae on the hard palate and tenderness on palpation of his extremities. On imaging, Pelkan spurs were seen on x-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of pain in the limbs along with purpuric rash, bleeding gums, petechiae, and the x-ray finding of Pelkan spurs, is highly suggestive of scurvy.

Radiological findings in scurvy:

  • Frankel's line - Zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis is dense, giving a white line called the Frankel's line.
  • Pelkan spurs - These are metaphyseal spurs formed due to fractures manifesting at the cortical margins. 
  • Wimberger’s ring sign - The sclerotic rim around the epiphysis forms this appearance.
  • Trummerfeld zone - Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line.

 

Scurvy:

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C and in this condition, there is the defective formation of connective tissue and collagen in the skin, bone, cartilage, dentine, and blood vessels which leads to their fragility.

Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages. Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Other options:

Option A: Rickets presents with skeletal changes like bowing of legs and bone pain. Radiological features show cupping at metaphysics, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta presents with the hallmark features of osteoporosis with increased fragility of bones along with blue sclera, dental fragility as well as hearing loss.

Option D: Osteopetrosis is also known as 'marble bone disease' where bones become sclerotic and thick, but their abnormal structure makes them weak and brittle.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of shortness of breath and dyspnoea at night. There is no history of bronchial asthma. Investigations revealed the presence of pulmonary venous hypertension. Which of the following is the earliest radiographic finding seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The earliest radiological finding in pulmonary venous hypertension is the enlargement of the upper zone vessels.

Pulmonary venous hypertension:

It is seen in conditions with impaired left ventricular function. Any left-sided pathology that impaired the forward flow of flood from the heart will cause a rise in left atrial pressure. This increase in pressure is transmitted from the atria to the pulmonary veins producing pulmonary venous hypertension.

Radiological findings in pulmonary venous hypertension:

  • Enlargement of upper zone blood vessels - the first radiological finding seen
  • Mild haziness in the lower zone with attenuation of lower zone vessels
  • Loss of definition of heart and mediastinal contours - This occurs as the normal sharp interface is obscured by the extravascular fluid
  • Kerley B lines- Horizontal subpleural lines, 1 cm in length and 1-3 mm in thickness, usually seen at the costophrenic angle. They indicate interstitial edema
  • Thickening of the interlobar fissure due to interstitial edema
  • Pulmonary effusions that are large and bilateral may be also seen
  • Long-standing cases can produce two additional findings:
    • Hemosiderosis: fine punctate calcifications scattered throughout the lung
    • Pulmonary ossific nodules: Small areas of bone formation in the lung seen in long-standing severe cases.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female child who was evaluated for visual field defects is found to have an optic glioma. On examination, there is also the presence of axillary freckling in the patient. There is a history of a similar condition in her family. Which of the following is a radiographic finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of optic glioma, axillary freckling, and positive family history are suggestive of neurofibromatosis 1(NF 1) and the ribbon-shaped appearance of the ribs is a characteristic finding in this condition.

Neurofibromatosis is an autosomal dominant disorder. NF-1 is the most prevalent type and is caused by loss of function mutation of the NF-1 gene.

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules
  • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma.
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A first degree relative with NF-1

Radiological findings in neurofibromatosis:

  • Scoliosis - Usually involving short segments of the thoracic spine
  • Posterior scalloping of the vertebral bodies
  • Pseudoarthrosis of long bones - This is particularly seen in the tibia and is characterized by marked absorption of fracture margins
  • Abnormal rib tubulation produces a characteristic ribbon-shaped appearance.
  • Notching of the ribs
  • Aplasia/ hypoplasia of the sphenoid wings

An image showing ribbon-shaped ribs is given below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Luxatio erecta - It refers to the inferior dislocation of the shoulder joint.

 

Option B: Oar-shaped ribs - It is the characteristic appearance of the ribs in Hurler's syndrome (MPS 1).

 

Option D: Terry Thomas sign (also called tooth gap sign) is seen in scapholunate dissociation. It is a large gap seen between the scaphoid and lunate. The sign is named after Terry Thomas who was an English comedian.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic man is being evaluated for intracranial pathology on a contrast enhanced CT scan.  His lab reports showed a GFR of 50mg/dL. So the radiologist decided to use a suitable water-soluble contrast. Which of the following contrast agents would be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is an elderly diabetic with GFR<60 mg/dL. Iohexol would be preferred to reduce the risk of contrast nephropathy. 

Iohexol is a non-ionic, low-osmolar water-soluble contrast agent. These contrast agents produce fewer abnormalities in the renal blood flow, thus causing less endothelial damage.

Water-soluble iodinated contrast agents are classified based on the osmolarity:

  • Low-osmolar - iohexol
  • Iso-osmolar - a subtype of low-osmolar contrast agent. example - iodixanol
  • High-osmolar - gastrograffin

Contrast nephropathy (CIN) is defined as a rise in serum creatinine by 0.5 mg/dl within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. Some risk factors include:

  • Older age
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Congestive heart failure
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction

Prevention of CIN: Adequate hydration with normal saline or administration of sodium bicarbonate before and after the procedure. 

Other options:

Option B: Gadolinium is a contrast agent used in MRI, whereas the patient in the given scenario is undergoing CT. 

Option C: Gastrograffin is a high-osmolar water-soluble contrast agent. 

Option D: Lipoidol is a water-insoluble agent used for sclerotherapy or hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: The characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image below is ________.
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the spinnaker sail sign, which is seen in pneumomediastinum.

Spinnaker sail sign is a chest x-ray finding in neonates with pneumomediastinum. The elevated thymus is outlined by air, and each lobe of the thymus is displaced laterally (because of air in the mediastinum), producing the appearance of spinnaker sails.

Other radiographic findings in pneumomediastinum:

  • Ring around the artery sign- It occurs due to air around the pulmonary artery.
  • Continuous diaphragm sign - In AP view, the air trapped posterior to the pericardium produces an appearance of continuous collection of air.
  • Extrapleural sign - Air extends laterally between the parietal pleura and the diaphragm.
  • Tubular artery sign - It occurs due to air around the major branches of the aorta.
  • Double bronchial wall sign - It occurs due to air around the bronchus, producing a clear depiction of the bronchial wall.

Three main causes of pneumomediastinum:

  1. Alveolar rupture with dissection of air into the mediastinum
  2. Perforation or rupture of the esophagus, trachea, or main bronchi
  3. Dissection of air from the neck or the abdomen into the mediastinum

Other options:

Option A: Cupola sign is a supine chest/abdominal radiograph finding in pneumoperitoneum. It is seen in the supine position as the gas within the abdominal cavity rises and accumulates underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline. It appears as a lucency overlying the lower thoracic vertebral bodies.

 

Option B: Falciform ligament sign is seen in pneumoperitoneum and refers to the falciform ligament being outlined by the free abdominal gas.

 

Option C: Rigler’s sign is also known as double-wall sign, and it is an abdominal radiograph finding in pneumoperitoneum. As seen in the image, both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible.

questions.text: All the following are indications of Tc 99m DMSA renal scintigraphy except _______.

choices.text: Direct measurement of glomerular filtration rate

questions.solution:
Direct measurement of GFR is done using Tc 99m DTPA, not Tc 99m DMSA. 

Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is a radiopharmaceutical agent used to evaluate renal structure and morphology. It is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents. It gives a static image.

The main use of Tc-99m DMSA is in assessing differential renal function and detection of renal scarring and pyelonephritis, especially in the pediatric population.

Indications for Tc-99m DMSA examination:

  • Assessment of differential renal function 
  • Assessment for focal parenchymal defects
  • Confirmation of acute pyelonephritis
  • Differentiating a multicystic dysplastic kidney from a hydronephrotic kidney
  • Assessment of renal function in children with cystic renal disease
  • Assessment of which kidney to biopsy in patients with bilateral renal involvement
  • Assessment of focal defects in a hypertensive child
  • Assessment of DRF in children undergoing abdominal radiotherapy where the kidneys are in the therapy field
  • Assessment of functioning renal tissue in children having bilateral Wilms’ tumor where renal conservation surgery is planned.

Note: Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion. Hence it is used for direct measurement of GFR.

questions.text:
The sign shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
  1. Drowning
  2. Bacterial meningitis
  3. Birth asphyxia
  4. Encephalitis
questions.solution:
The above CT scan image shows a reversal sign or white cerebellum sign or dense cerebellum sign. It is seen in conditions causing a diffuse decrease in density of the supratentorial brain parenchyma, with a relative increase in attenuation of the thalami, brainstem, and cerebellum.  It indicates irreversible brain damage and is associated with poor prognosis.

The reversal sign is seen in the following conditions:

  • Drowning
  • Bacterial meningitis
  • Birth asphyxia
  • Encephalitis
  • Severe head injury
  • Status epilepticus

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of severe headache for 1 week which is not relieved with analgesics. A brain CT was done revealed a suprasellar mass as shown below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
This unenhanced CT showing a calcified cystic structure in the suprasellar region, along with dilated ventricles (hydrocephalus), is suggestive of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are relatively benign neoplasms that typically arise in the suprasellar region. They are derived from the remnants of Rathke cleft and have bimodal age distribution.

The two variants of craniopharyngioma are:

  • Adamantinomatous - It is seen in children. Calcification is characteristic of this variety.
  • Papillary - It is seen in adults. Wet keratin nodules are the characteristic histologic feature of this type.

Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Craniopharyngiomas tend not to expand the pituitary fossa unless they become very large, which is a differentiating feature from pituitary macroadenomas.

The image given below shows a T1-weighted MRI brain showing craniopharyngioma in a sagittal view.

Other options:

Option B: Pituitary macroadenomas are seen in the sellar region. Calcifications are mostly absent in contrast to craniopharyngiomas. In addition, on imaging, indentation at the diaphragma sellae gives rise to a snowman/figure of eight appearance/cottage loaf.

The image below shows the snowman appearance seen in pituitary macroadenomas.

Option C: Meningioma is mainly a supratentorial tumor, commonly seen in the parasagittal region.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.
